content.description:
This is a mixed gear/sport route.

The slab has three routes on it but the biggest one is a spooky run out slab climb on dirty rock. Like most of the bolted climbs along the river road, certain bolts and anchors have been updated and are trustworthy.

Start at the base of the center of the slab and gradually climb up into steeper rock. You will notice this climb from the road because of how featured with knobs and chicken heads it is.
content.location: Before the bridge soon after the road turns to dirt

content.description:
The appeal with this climb is that it stays in the shade almost all day

Pitch One

: build a belay anchor at the base of a corner system that opens to the right.

Scramble up some mossy ledges and blocks and begin aiding up the corner. There’s a fixed knife blade I left on this section. Perhaps someone taller than I won’t have a need to clip it.

You’ll soon come to an arcing roof, climb through it, placing a mix of cams and good nuts until you reach the arching, hollow flake above and climb it until you reach the lower out bolt. Belay here.

* A note on the hollow flake. I nearly fell when a .3 Camelot tipped-out when the flake "flexed out"/ expanded a bit, so be a little cautious. otherwise the aid is very straight forward, and a free ascent is very possible.

Pitch Two:

Lower off the bolt down to the right and commence climbing in a dihedral below the small, 90 degree angle roof. There should probably be a bolted belay anchor after this traverse as the crack here is quite thin; I used an offset BD #1/2 cam. From here there is an angle iron piton that makes reaching an easy hook move even easier. Aid up through the roof and continue climbing through the filthy splitter fist crack until you reach the ledge. There’s a tricam and mediocre feeling angle iron piton that were used for rappelling.

Pitch Three:

to avoid the menace of the shrubbery, use the layback/ jam crack that goes up the left side and then when the crack ends make a slight traverse right and into the main chimney system. It should be noted that the upper chimney section is probably R rated, but the rock is good and grippy, (I climbed it in a pair of Merrel hiking boots). Continue to the top.

Descent: Sling the service berry shrubs and rappel. Bolted rappel station soon to come.
content.protection: Fixed pitons, 1 bat hook, doubles in Camelot’s from 00-3, singles in Camelot’s 4-6, and a double set of stoppers.
content.location:
This climb is located 200 feet before the bridge  and across the river and is the most prominent buttress along that particular section of the canyon.

The rock is most easily accessed with a boat and If you wait till mid July you’ll have the easiest time fording.

There is a pullout on the right side of the road just before the manning crevice bridge. Park here, unload your gear, and put on. P

addle right across the river and eddy out down river from the rock.

content.description: This crack was aid soloed and hasn’t been lead free yet. I thought initially the crack would be more moderate but it has two fixed pitons down low and then moves into a finger crack and widens to fist. The transition one must make from  aid to free is a bummer but if you carefully climb up the left side of the obelisk with a BIG piece of webbing you could sling the left side of the crack and set up a top rope without too much hassle. The cracks edges are rounded out and the right side juts out a little further than the left.
content.protection:
Two fixed pitons, old #4 Camelot and large hex are at the top for rappelling. Bring extra tat to back up the old stuff.

This route is heavy on #3 & 4 Camelot’s.
content.location: You can see the yellow striped, pointed face of The Obelisk from the bridge. The approach looks more daunting than it really is. Simply walk to where the bridge cables anchor into the hill and walk up and left to gain the Ridge and then contour back right.

content.description: Start on the red tinted rock and move up to a tiny roof. Follow bolt line up the face of the rock to a great slanted crack going up the rock. One little reachy move towards the tree on the right in the middle of the climb. The there is some moves at the top that involve walking on the dirt and grass on the rock. Can be top roped if you hike up to the right of the formation and around.
content.protection: 8 Bolts and two anchors at the top with rap rings. All look new and really nice!
content.location: Coming from the Manning Crevice Bridge it is .4 miles on the right. Across the river when the water is at the right level, there is a beach with a little over hanging rock. One of the few fully bolted routes around.

content.description: This is the best, most fun climb up the river road. It offers a short approach and great rock.  There are two bolted rap station at the top. The top 8 meters of the climb are runout scrambling over dirt and loose grass to the anchors. Use two ropes to rap. On this same formation are three other routes as well. One of them is a heinous run out slab climb, the other two are cracks. Above these climbs is a sweet splitter crack as well. It lies left of center on a triangular face.
content.protection: Multiples of #2's and down. There are anchors at the top. 8 meter runout at the top of the climb scrambling over bushes and loose dirt.
content.location: Coming from the Manning Crevice Bridge it is .4 miles on the right. Across from the climb on the other side of the river there is a small beach with an overhanging rock over the beach. As soon as the road turns to dirt you should start paying attention. The side of the buttress that “salmon river quiver” is on May be seen from the pull out. Park at this pull out which is on the river side, in front of the climb.

content.description: Climb under the roof or up the arete to reach the roof and jam to the top.
content.location: Next to the Diamond Back Crack at the Manning Crevice.

content.description:
Quite an excellent pitch. #3’s nearly all the way up until you hit an off width pod of sorts that takes a .5, .75, and or number 1 Camelot. This is a sweet, lichen-free splitter crack that ends on a nice clean ledge to belay from.

At the high ledge, slung around a large block is some very, very old and rotten webbing. There is only that one strand which makes me think that the the route has hardly been climbed. The first time I did this route I didn’t bother to scramble to the upper ledge and so without seeing the ancient webbing, thought I’d done the FA

But

Some enterprising, and unknown crack jammer spotted the line apparently long before me.
content.protection: Hex and webbing are in place for rappelling.  Bring #’s .5, .75, 2, 3 (x’s 3), & 4 BD Camelot’s.
content.location:
Same approach as for Egg Shell.

Walk upriver on a trail thats reached by walking to the left of the Crevice Bridge, past diamond back crack. Climb is visible from both sides of the river.

Walk to the base of the rock formation and head up the grassy slopes at foot of the cliff.

Scramble up to the base of the ledge from the uphill side where you’ll find a short stem box (maybe 15 feet tall), where a huge block leans up against the main face. Some parties may chose to pitch this out.

Scramble fourth class terrain past eggshell and Continue down a ramp and then back up the ramp to the base of the climb  where you have a scenic belay waiting. Build an anchor here.

content.description:
I wish the eggshell part went on for another 100 feet!

Though small, this is a fun little climb that involves a little lie backing and jamming up a wide flake Resembling an eggshell peeling off of the mountain.

Pitch 2: From the top of the eggshell pitch, build an anchor and traverse out right and up the crack system to the top of the formation. once at the top, walk to your left and find a small tree to rappel from.
content.protection:
Bring large gear and several #2 or #1 Camelot’s for the belay anchor. Large stoppers also recommended.

There is a 1.5 inch diameter pine tree slung with webbing to rappel on but bring extra webbing as the rodents will have no doubt eaten the old sling! Back the tree up with a .5 & .75 Camelot in the short, vertical crack right of the tree if your buddy is rappelling first.
content.location:
Approach:

Park at or before the bridge and walk up the road a bit and go left at the bridge, just as for the Diamond Back Crack. Walk past diamond back crack along a little trail that heads upriver. From this trail you’ll be able to see the two routes just above the trail on your left. Walk the trail until you’re at the base of the rock formation and then walk up the slick, grassy slope to the base of the climbs. Once standing under the climbs, hike to the upper left side and scramble up to the ledge from where you’ll belay.

content.description:
The crack is so named because during bridge reconstruction a saw cut into the rock face leaving elliptical indents resembling serpentine scales.

During the bridges 2017 reconstruction a diamond back nest under the crack was found to be troublesome for bridge workers, so the construction foreman used old people tongs to pinch rattlers and throw them into a cooler for relocation.
content.protection: 1 TR bolt. If climbing with crash pads a spotter is a good idea
